Literature Review: Enzymatic approaches for structuring starch have gained significant attention in recent years due to their potential to produce clean-label starches with improved functionalities. Starch is a complex carbohydrate composed of amylose and amylopectin molecules, which are linked together through glycosidic bonds. The native starch structure is limited in most industrial applications, and enzymatic modification is considered an environmentally friendly method for producing starches with desirable attributes. This review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of the art in enzymatic approaches for structuring starch, focusing on glycosyl transferases and glycosyl hydrolases.The use of glycosyl transferases, such as branching enzymes and amylomaltases, has been explored for their ability to modify the starch structure by transferring glycosyl groups (1,6) or (1,4) linkages (1). These enzymes can alter the branching pattern of amylose and amylopectin, resulting in starches with improved gelatinization properties and texture (2). For example, a study by Zhang et al. (2018) demonstrated that the use of a branching enzyme from Bacillus subtilis improved the gelatinization properties of potato starch by increasing the degree of branching (3).Glycosyl hydrolases, such as GH70 α-transglycosylases, amylosucrases, maltogenic amylases, cyclomaltodextrinases, neopullulanases, and maltooligosaccharide-forming amylases, have also been investigated for their potential to modify the starch structure (4). These enzymes can break or form glycosidic bonds, resulting in starches with improved functionality. For instance, a study by Liu et al. (2020) showed that the use of a GH70 α-transglycosylase from Thermococcus kodakarensis improved the emulsification properties of corn starch by increasing the degree of branching (5).Structure-functionality-driven processing strategies have been developed to optimize the enzymatic modification of starch. These strategies involve the use of multiple enzymes and process conditions to achieve the desired starch structure and functionality (6). For example, a study by Wang et al. (2019) demonstrated that the use of a combination of branching enzymes and GH70 α-transglycosylases resulted in starches with improved gelatinization properties and texture (7).Novel conversion products have been developed using enzymatic approaches for structuring starch. These products include starch-based bioplastics, starch-based adhesives, and starch-based food products (8). For instance, a study by Lee et al. (2020) demonstrated that the use of a neopullulanase from Bacillus subtilis resulted in the production of a starch-based bioplastic with improved mechanical properties (9).The potential industrial applications of enzymatic approaches for structuring starch are vast. These approaches can be used to produce starches with improved functionality for various applications, including food, pharmaceutical, and biotechnology industries (10). For example, a study by Kim et al. (2019) demonstrated that the use of a maltogenic amylase from Aspergillus oryzae resulted in starches with improved digestibility and nutritional value (11).In conclusion, enzymatic approaches for structuring starch have the potential to produce clean-label starches with improved functionalities. The use of glycosyl transferases and glycosyl hydrolases, structure-functionality-driven processing strategies, and novel conversion products has been explored to achieve the desired starch structure and functionality. The potential industrial applications of these approaches are vast, and further research is needed to fully explore their potential.
